Award.AwardTitle: Support of Nanophotonics Incubator: Beyond Classical Limits Incubator Meeting from May 14-16th, 2014 in Washington, DC.

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to support a meeting titled Nanophotonic Device: Beyond Classical Limits from May 14-16th, 2014 at the OSA in Washington, DC. USA. This support will permit top-notch experts in nanophotonics to deliver plenary talks on recent advances and future research directions. This meeting will allow researchers, engineers and business leaders a valuable opportunity to meet and discuss challenges and opportunities regarding research in nanophotonics technology. Results of the meeting will impact photonic computing solutions, sensitive point-of-care diagnostics, and revolutions in next generation solar cells.

Over the last decade, on-chip integrated photonic circuits have shown great potential for big-data bandwidth applications. However, while the photonic device performance is steadily increasing, the inherently weak light-matter-interactions set fundamental limits to integration density, bandwidth, and drive power consumption. The goal of this meeting is to determine the next revolutionary steps of photonics technologies for communication and optical computing. Emerging nanophotonics materials, optical confinement options, and integration schemes will be discussed, analyzed, and planned.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Nanophotonics Incubator meeting, "Beyond Classical Limits",
held May 2014 in Washington DC was to determine ultimate device limitations
while suggesting potential solutions of expertise to overcome them. Expertise,
vision, and insights, from academia industry, and government were shared,
discussed and gathered, resulting in an accelerated pathway for future research and shortened communication between all players.

The conference assembled the key leaders in the field to present
recent advancements in Nanophotonics to discuss future developments and
applications. Over the last decade on-chip integrated optoelectronic circuits
such as the silicion and III-V platforms showed great potential big-data
bandwidth applications. However, while the photonic device performance is
steadily increasing, the inherently weak light-matter-interactions (LMI) sets
fundamental limits to critical performance metrics such as footprints
(Integration Density), speed (Bandwidth), and drive power. The meeting
discussions advanced the leading edge of this technology by bringing together
researchers from the impacted disciplines to define and answer their
emerging needs of the next decades.

Broader impact provided by this meeting included it
being instrumental in defining the research required by the growing
demands of Naonphotonics. This Topical Meeting of the Optical Society of
America contributed to the training of participating students and topics were
disseminated through the Conference Technical Digest.

OSA initiated the Incubator form of meeting in 2011 to provide unique and focused experiences, allowing researchers, engineers and business leaders of niche fields a valuable opportunity to meet and discuss advances, challenges and opportunities regarding their research. Rather than a presentation and lecture style meeting, Incubators are intimate, interactive meetings driven from topics suggested by academia or industry professionals and guided by our staff Science Advisors by pulling together attendees that lead in the topic area. The invitees are diverse and come prepared to network, dialogue and discover—with the goal of applied learning.
